introduction.p: Last section, we categorized polynomials by the long-run behavior. We now take a closer look at how these functions behave for smaller x-values. In particular, we see how the polynomial behaves around its roots.

subsection.title: x-Intercepts (roots) and Short-Run Behavior
subsection.p: We have seen before that the x-intercepts of a quadratic polynomial, f(x) = ax^2 + bx + c, occur at values of x for which f(x) = 0, that is, at the real-valued solutions of the equation ax^2 + bx + c = 0. The same holds true for polynomials of higher degree.

Solutions of the equation P(x) = 0 are called zeros of the polynomial P. In , we graphed the cubic polynomial P(x) = x^3 - 4x. Its x-intercepts are the solutions of the equation x^3 - 4x = 0, which we can solve by factoring the polynomial P(x).
x^3 - 4x \amp= 0
x(x - 2)(x + 2) \amp= 0
The zeros of P are 0, 2, and -2. Each zero of P corresponds to a linear factor of P(x). This result suggests the following theorem, which holds for any polynomial P.
Because a polynomial function of degree n can have at most n linear factors of the form (x - a), it follows that P can have at most n distinct zeros.

Another way of saying this is that if P(x) is a polynomial of nth degree, the equation P(x) = 0 can have at most n distinct solutions, some of which may be complex numbers. (We do not cover complex numbers in this course but there are plenty of reasonable resources available online if you wish to know more.)
Because only real-valued solutions appear on the graph as x-intercepts, we have the following corollary to the factor theorem.

assemblage.title: x-Intercepts of Polynomials
assemblage.p: A polynomial of degree n can have at most n x-intercepts.

subsection.p: If some of the zeros of P are complex numbers, they will not appear on the graph, so a polynomial of degree n may have fewer than n x-intercepts.

statement.p:
Find the real-valued zeros of each of the following polynomials, and list the x-intercepts of its graph.
f(x) = x^3 + 6x^2 + 9x
g(x) = x^4 - 3x^2 - 4

li.p:
Factor the polynomial to obtain
f(x) \amp= x(x^2 + 6x + 9)
\amp= x(x + 3)(x + 3).
By the factor theorem, the zeros of f are 0, -3, and -3. (We say that f has a zero of multiplicity two at -3.) Because all of these are real numbers, all will appear as x-intercepts on the graph. Thus, the x-intercepts occur at (0, 0) and at (-3, 0).

Factor the polynomial to obtain
g(x) \amp= (x^2 - 4)(x^2 + 1)
\amp= (x - 2)(x + 2)(x^2 + 1).
Because x^2 + 1 cannot be factored in real numbers, the graph has only two x-intercepts, at (-2, 0) and (2, 0). Hence, g(x) has only x=-2 and x=2 as its zeros. The graphs of both polynomials are shown in .

subsection.title: Zeros of Multiplicity Two or Three
subsection.p: The appearance of the graph near an x-intercept is determined by the multiplicity of the zero there. For example, both real zeros of the polynomial g(x) = x^4 - 3x^2 - 4 in b are of multiplicity one, and the graph crosses the x-axis at each intercept.
However, the polynomial f(x) = x^3 + 6x^2 + 9x in a has a zero of multiplicity two at x = -3. The graph of f just touches the x-axis and then reverses direction without crossing the axis.
To understand what happens in general, compare the graphs of the three polynomials in .

image.description: plots of a linear, quadratic, and cubic, each with a single zero

li.p: In a, L(x) = x - 2 has a zero of multiplicity one at x = 2, and its graph crosses the x-axis there.
In b, Q(x) = (x - 2)^2 has a zero of multiplicity two at x = 2, and its graph touches the x-axis there but changes direction without crossing.
In c, C(x) = (x - 2)^3 has a zero of multiplicity three at x = 2. In this case, the graph makes an S-shaped curve at the intercept, like the graph of y = x^3.

subsection.p: Near its x-intercepts, the graph of a polynomial takes one of the characteristic shapes illustrated in .

assemblage.title: Multiplicities of Roots
assemblage.p:
Let f(x) be a polynomial function.
At a root of even multiplicity the graph of f(x) bounces off the x-axis.
At a root of odd multiplicity the graph of f(x) crosses the x-axis.

note.p: Although we will not consider zeros of multiplicity greater than three, they correspond to similar behavior in the graph: At a zero of odd multiplicity, the graph has an inflection point at the intercept; its graph makes an S-shaped curve. At a zero of even multiplicity, the graph has a turning point; it changes direction without crossing the x-axis.

solution.p: The polynomial has degree six, an even number, so its graph starts at the upper left and extends to the upper right. The y-coordinate of the y-intercept is f(0) = (2)^3(-1)(-3)^2 = -72. Note that f has a zero of multiplicity three at x = -2, a zero of multiplicity one at x = 1, and a zero of multiplicity two at x = 3. The graph has an S-shaped curve at x = -2, crosses the x-axis at x = 1, touches the x-axis at x = 3, and then changes direction, as shown in .
